p: Up to 70% of adults in tropical regions of Asia have JEV antibodies. An estimated 50,000 cases occur every year where the most acutely infected patients are children or non-immune individuals [ 136]. Clinical infections are severe with a case fatality rate of 30% or severe neurologic sequels in up to 50% of the patients [ 137]. JEV infections occur all year long in South Asian countries while they occur during summer in temperate regions [ 138]. The infection in animals is subclinical, however, it causes abortion in pregnant sows and death in newborn piglets [ 139]. JEV causes inapparent infection in horses, but neurologic signs are observed occasionally with a high fatality rate. Seroepidemiological studies show that JEV can incidentally infect a variety of other vertebrates, including dogs, ducks, chickens, cattle, bats, snakes, and frogs [ 130].
